bestBHT.bht: When the demon-possessed man saw Jesus from a distance, he ran and worshipped him. His rapid and involuntary response demonstrates the power of Jesus over the demonic forces. Although the man's worship was reluctant, even hostile, it revealed an acknowledgment of Christ's authority. This encounter reveals the secret exercise of Jesus' authority, compelling those under Satan's dominion to approach and worship him against their will. It exemplifies Christ's superiority over the demons and serves as an emblem of an awakened sinner, recognizing Christ's ability to save and hastening to bow before him.

Henry Alford: 6.] afar off and ran are peculiar to Mark.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: But when he saw Jesus afar off, he ran and worshipped him—not with the spontaneous alacrity which says to Jesus, 'Draw me, we will run after thee.'
Inwardly compelled, with terrific rapidity, before the Judge, to receive sentence of expulsion.
Before the Judge, to receive sentence of expulsion.
Marvin Vincent: Afar off [απο μακροθεν] . Peculiar to Mark, as is also he ran.
John Calvin: We ought to be aware that they did not come of their own accord into the presence of Christ, but were drawn by a secret exercise of his authority.
Hence we infer, that the whole of Satan’s kingdom is subject to the authority of Christ.
Reluctantly too they worship him, and their rebellious complaints testify that their confession was not made from choice, but was drawn from them by force.
Philip Schaff: The prominent thought is that he ran from a distance. This running would look like a violent attack, but instead of this, he worshipped him."
But the next verse intimates that it was an acknowledgment of Christ’s power, even if still hostile in its tone."
If the man was merely insane, how could he have known of Jesus.
Archibald T. Robertson: The onrush of the naked yelling maniac must have tried the newly recovered confidence of the Twelve.
We can imagine their surprise when, on approaching, he threw himself on his knees.
John Gill: such was the power of Christ over the devils in him, that though sore against their wills, they obliged him to move on speedily towards him; so that he ran and worshipped him
This is an instance of the superiority of Christ over the devils, who knowing who he is, are filled with horror at him, fall down before him, and in their way do homage to him
an emblem of a poor awakened sinner, having a distant sight of Christ, who, upon it, makes haste unto him, and prostrates itself before him, believing he is able, if willing, to save him

bhtAttempts.bht: When the demon-possessed man saw Jesus from a distance, he ran and worshiped him. His quick response, though not a willing one, is a testament to the power and authority of Jesus. The man's violent outburst may have tested the newfound confidence of the Twelve as they approached. Yet, in his worship, there was an acknowledgment of Christ's power, even if still tinged with hostility. This encounter reveals the secret exercise of Jesus' authority, compelling those under Satan's dominion to approach and worship him, albeit reluctantly. It exemplifies Christ's superiority over the demons, as they fall before him and pay homage, even against their will, just as an awakened sinner, catching a distant glimpse of Christ, makes haste to prostrate themselves before him, believing in his ability to save.

When the demon-possessed man saw Jesus from a distance, he ran and worshipped him. His rapid and involuntary response demonstrates the power of Jesus over the demonic forces. Although the man's worship was reluctant, even hostile, it revealed an acknowledgment of Christ's authority. This encounter reveals the secret exercise of Jesus' authority, compelling those under Satan's dominion to approach and worship him against their will. It exemplifies Christ's superiority over the demons and serves as an emblem of an awakened sinner, recognizing Christ's ability to save and hastening to bow before him.

When the demonic man spotted Jesus from afar, he raced towards Him and prostrated himself in worship. This swift and reluctant gesture showcased the overwhelming authority Jesus held over the forces of darkness. The demons, though compelled against their will, succumbed to His power, falling at His feet. This encounter highlights Christ's supremacy over the spiritual realm, proving that even the most defiant entities are subject to His divine command. It serves as a poignant depiction of a repentant sinner, catching a glimpse of Christ and eagerly seeking His salvation.

In Mark 5:6, as Jesus comes into view, the demon-possessed man runs towards Him and worships Him. This hasty and reluctant act reveals the unstoppable authority of Jesus over the demonic realm. Despite their resistance, the demons are compelled to acknowledge His power and submit to His presence. This encounter underscores the superiority of Jesus over Satan's forces, demonstrating His ability to bring even the most rebellious beings to their knees. It serves as a vivid representation of a sinner, catching sight of Christ from afar, rushing towards Him, and seeking His deliverance.

As Jesus appeared in the distance, the demon-possessed man sprinted toward Him, falling to his knees in worship. This impulsive act, driven by an inner compulsion, reflects the authority and power of Jesus. Even against their will, the demons recognized His supremacy and were compelled to approach Him. This encounter demonstrates Christ's complete dominion over the forces of darkness, as they reluctantly but unambiguously acknowledged His ability to save and deliver.
